pullRequest.body:
Also a bit of reorganization around the whole (short) file. This will be used for constructing non-unital functional calculi.

Co-authored-by: @j-loreaux 

---

nodes.body:
Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9250641996/job/25444577834)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9250641996/job/25444577384)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9250641996/job/25444577593)
shouldn't there be a space before the opening parenthesis?
(I tried, and the answer is no, but I don't understand the trick — what does $ do?)

`congr(...)` is special syntax for creating congruence lemmas. For example, if `h : a = b`, then `congr(f $h)` gives that `f a = f b`. No space is how it's distinguished from the `congr` lemma.

The congruence in question can be written as `congr(⟨⟨$h, _⟩, _⟩)` without the additional parentheses.
Here, it would be enough to assume that `{0 : R}` is closed.

I feel this is a case where the loss of generality is acceptable for the following reasons:
- the version you describe would be slightly more annoying to use because we wouldn't have the typeclass system to infer the arguments in the obvious cases.
- I don't expect the more general version to be useful. First because there's not a bunch of interesting examples where the distinction would matter (e.g in a topological group the two conditions are equivalent), second because this type is really an ad-hoc definition meant for one specific application (the more general setup would be pointed continuous maps where you allow more freedom on the point).
- Finally, if someone ever needs this generalization it would be very easy to add.

Does that make sense?
It does, especially because the `R` is likely to be `Real`.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: uniform structure on ContinuousMapZero
